awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Spoken Language Variation in Chanka, an Endangered Language
awd_abstract_narration:
Social and linguistic factors related to standard language ideologies have been found to affect the patterning of linguistic variables in well-known languages. However, in indigenous speech communities, it is not well understood whether the same factors predict variation in the same way, given that social factors (especially education-related ideologies) can be quite different. This project investigates which factors constrain variation in an endangered indigenous language of South America. The documentation will form the core material to be analyzed in a doctoral dissertation. Broader impacts include a publicly available deposit of the recordings, transcriptions, and metadata, as well as community training in data collection and linguistic analysis. Results from this work thus directly encourage language maintenance by empowering community-driven documentation and facilitating the creation of accurate pedagogical materials.

Natalie Povilonis de Vilchez, a doctoral candidate at New York University, will conduct and analyze sociolinguistic interviews in the Chanka variety of Quechua, spoken in Peru. Studying Chanka offers insight into how sociolinguistic theories apply to situations where indigenous languages are rarely appropriate for education or formal domains, and where speakers have varied fluency in the majority language (Spanish). While endangered, Chanka continues to be a vital code for many speakers, thus allowing documentation of the language in actual use. This project will develop a transcribed corpus of approximately 64 hours of sociolinguistic interviews with speakers in four communities, selected as proxies for differences in Spanish fluency, ruralness, and education. Traditional variationist qualitative methods, often involving reading tasks, are adapted as audiovisual activities to determine how non-literate speakers evaluate different ways of speaking. The quantitative analysis focuses on rates of use of both a phonological variable that is the object of conscious correction (the uvular phoneme), and morphosyntactic variables below the level of speaker awareness (word order and related determiners and case marking).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project documented variation in spoken Andahuaylas Chanka Quechua (Peru), utilizing adapted sociolinguistic methodologies. Interviews with 56 rural and urban speakers were recorded, transcribed (time-aligned), translated, and publicly archived. Rapidly increasing urban migration and assimilatory pressure in the city have led to a widespread shift to Spanish for economic and social gain. This means that urban Quechua has much more contact with Spanish than rural speech.

 The language shift appears to contradict official discourse, which celebrates linguistic and ethnic diversity. The goal of this discourse is national integration based on a common rich cultural history, to which Indigenous people are the crucial link. Thus, to support cultural and language maintenance, Peru’s Ministry of Education developed a standard orthography and began teaching Quechua in schools in the late twentieth century. However, significant divergences between the ‘standard’ school Quechua and spoken dialects serve to delegitimize speakers who do not use idealized forms. Ultimately, in the national discourse framework, Indigeneity refers to a homogenous, monolithic category that necessarily includes antiquity, rurality, agriculturalism, and poverty—as well as the Quechua language, but only in an authentic form. For social mobility, one must superar ‘overcome’ all associated characteristics to become a modern, urban, mestizo professional. Since mestizos necessarily speak Spanish and use Quechua in fewer domains, their Quechua does not fit into the authentic ideal.

Using data from interviews with 32 rural and urban Chanka Quechua speakers, the quantitative analysis considers two variable features and the social and linguistic factors that constrain them. The first variable is variable presence of the uvular phoneme in the exhortative (rirquni ~ riruni ‘I have gone’) and experiential past tense morphemes (rirqani ~ rirani ‘I went’). The second variable is word order, subject-object-verb versus subject-verb-object (SOV ñuqa misita rikuni ~ SVO ñuqa rikuni misita ‘I see a cat’), and related determiners and case marking. My analysis has found that less educated speakers with lower Spanish proficiency are more likely to pronounce the uvular and follow canonical OV word order with fewer determiners. These speakers also tend to be older and rural. For word order, education plays a significant role: speakers with secondary education or above have lower rates of preverbal object positioning. Uvular alternation appears to be Quechua-internal though supported by bilingualism in Spanish. However, I argue that influence from Spanish morphosyntax is leading to word order variation, in line with research on other Quechua varieties.

These results validate the diversity of spoken Chanka, and broaden variationist sociolinguistic theories to language contact and marginalized languages. Results of the analysis show that urban migration and resulting Spanish contact has led to significant changes in Chanka features. By documenting widespread systematic variation in both features, this work contradicts perceptions of the fossilized nature of Quechua. Thus, these results can facilitate creation of accurate pedagogical materials that encourage speakers to maintain their unique Quechua regardless of divergence from putatively ‘standard’ or authentic forms, rather than switching to Spanish. Results also offer insight into applying traditionally Western theories to Indigenous language situations, where most speakers have limited literacy in the target language, and varied fluency in the majority language (Spanish).
